topic.title: HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade 2.0: Non-KVM Region Overview

titlealts.searchtitle: HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade: HP Helion OpenStack Overview

body.p: For installation and maintenance, HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade consists of three logical or conceptual regions: Non-KVM, KVM, and baremetal.
The Non-KVM region contains the lifecycle manager, to deploy and maintain HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade; and HP Helion OpenStack, a commercial-grade distribution of OpenStack.
Note: These regions do not function as OpenStack regions.
body.section:
Lifecycle ManagerAll four deployment models install the lifecycle manager into the non-KVM region.
The Non-KVM environment includes a full installation of a lifecycle manager, an application that is used to deploy HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade and can be used for ongoing operations and maintenance of the system.
Physical Node Preparation. The lifecycle manager can configure nodes prior to installation of a base operating system, including node discovery/inventory, BIOS configuration, (specifically setting PXE boot on primary interface), GRUB settings, RAID setup for local disks, iLO/IPMI set up and firmware upgrades.
OS Install. The lifecycle manager can take a PXE bootable node and installs a base operating system.
Cloud Configuration. The lifecycle manager can provide detailed information about the cloud topology, such as the structure of control plane, assignment of services to nodes, and service configuration. You can also specify environment-specific configurations.
OS Configuration. The lifecycle manager can automatically execute operating system configuration values, such as NIC assignments, NTP settings, DNS settings, NIC bonding, sysctl settings, VLAN creation and so forth. The lifecycle manager uses the Ansible data model output and server playbooks to automatically apply the per-node configurations.
Helion Operation & Maintenance. The lifecycle manager is responsible for the deploy, upgrade and maintenance lifecycle of the HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade system.

section.title: HP Helion OpenStack
section.p: All four deployment models install HP Helion OpenStack into the non-KVM region.

HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade is a carrier-grade distribution of OpenStack the leading open source cloud computing platform. This distribution, backed by HPE enables customers to more easily build, manage, and use open-source based hybrid cloud in a resilient, maintainable platform. HP Helion OpenStack enables cost-effective scalability of IT services and business agility and, as part of the HP Helion portfolio, it is backed by a wide range of related cloud products, services, and professional support.

HP Helion OpenStack offers many services based on the different OpenStack projects to provide the functionality you need. Visit the HP Helion OpenStack Services Overview page for a complete list of services.

section.title: HP Distributed Cloud Networking (DCN)
section.p: The Tahoe, Memphis, and Sacramento deployment models include HP DCN.

The optional HPE DCN is a software-Defined Networking (SDN) solution that enhances data center (DC) network virtualization by automatically establishing connectivity between compute resources upon their creation.

body.section:
ESX IntegrationThe Memphis, and Sacramento deployment models include VMWare ESX.
HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade optionally supports VMWare ESX hypervisor using HPE Distributed Cloud Networking (aka DCN). With our ESX integration, the cloud can provision and manage an ESX cluster. VMWare Compute Proxy is used as a part of ESX integration. The VMware vCenter driver connects to ESX clusters through Nova Compute proxy nodes. A Compute node scheduler sees each cluster as compute and uses the same for scheduling new instances.
DCN/ESX Integration
This DCN/ESX integration uses the VRSvAPP application to connect the VMware vCenterâ„¢ networking to the Network Operations controller to manage workload networks.
Virtual networking between HP Helion Carrier Grade and the ESX servers is handled by HPE Distributed Cloud Networking (DCN) is a software-defined networking (SDN) solution that enhances data center (DC) network virtualization by automatically establishing connectivity between compute resources upon their creation.
The ESX integration uses the OVSvApp application to connect the vCenter networking to the Network Operations controller to manage workload networks.
ESX region uses mixture of best features from OpenStack, ESX and DCN:
OpenStack features with rich services such as Keystone, Glance, Nova, Neutron, Cinder, Horizon
ESX provides foundation for building and managing a virtualized IT infrastructure
ESX provides reliability and performance
ESX hypervisor abstracts processor, memory and storage
DCN provides programmable business logic and a powerful policy engine
DCN provides open and highly responsive solution that scales and span across multi-tenant DCs
Inter-region and Inter-cloud communication between different data centers
ESX region uses VMDK driver using multi-backend storage support from Cinder
